chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: This book is about specific sub-sets of non-Jews. These subsets are either entirely mutually exclusive, or have only some mutual exclusivity in respect to their properties. For instance, all humans have chromosomes, but not all humans keep kosher; so the subsets are defined in respect to the properties talked about. This book is about specific subsets and their respective properties. These subsets or categories, are called gedarim in Hebrew.

Gedarim have certain properties associated with them. For instance, let's take a look at the word goy. The geder for goy is such that a goy that gives tzedakah/charity to bnei Yisrael: bnei Yisrael cannot benefit from that tzedakah and the tzedakah must be given instead to the goy poor. However, when a ben Noach/child of Noah, which is under a different geder gives charity to bnei Yisrael, the poor of bnei Yisrael can use that tzedakah. What is a goy? What is a ben Noach? Why are they treated differently? Many will tell you that the goy and the ben Noach are the same thing. However, they're not. These different categories of non-Jews will be explained in this book. This book will properly show some correct definitions and differences of these gedarim of non-Jews, which will expose many horrible translations or misunderstandings about quotes of Torah taken out of context to wrongfully justify de-huminization or hatred of the Jew and non-Jew.
"A ben Noach that wants to do a mitzvah/commandment from the other mitzvot of the Torah(beyond the seven of bnei Noach) in order to receive reward, [Yisrael] does not keep him from doing it properly. And if he brings a burnt offering, we receive it. If he gives tzedakah, we receive it from him and it appears to me that it is given to the poor of Yisrael. He receives his sustenance from Yisrael and it is a mitzvah to sustane his life. However, a goy that gives tzedakah, we receive it and give it to the poor goyim - R"AMBAM, Hilchot Melachim 10:10 This shows a good example of two different gedarim even though both goy and ben Noach are in the set of non-Jews. Gedarim and there given properties is mostly what this book is about.
